content.description:
A classic skaha climb. Fully sustained climbing at 5.11a. Great, vertical, technical, and pumpy.

Finishes under a small roof feature high up on the main wall.
13 bolts.

Climb to a super jug to clip the first bolt and then solve a difficult boulder involving all left facing holds and a couple of bad feet. Long draw your third bolt and launch into a compression sequence ending with a slap to another super bucket. 

One more mini-boulder gets you to rests/easy climbing to the roof (long draw bolts 5, 6). Take the right bolt branch and lay back the crack to the chains. Pumpy!

Left branch goes at 12c (FA Rick Leslie). 

Bolting down low seems a bit strange, the long draws help to straighten out the rope. This is likely a result of following hollow flakes that wouldn't take a bolt. 



2nd route from the right at Tottering Pillar, starts just left of the two living tree's that are against the wall. 

11 bolts, fixed anchor with biners.

Start up a ramp to an inverted block staircase. Use big side-pulls and underclings to delicately, and then powerfully surmount the mini roof. 

This is a short, awesome line worth the climb in itself, but is most commonly used as an approach pitch for the "Victoria Mordor" mega line.



Drop down the hill to the Tottering Pillar; look for the bolt line just before the trail passes the freestanding pine tree. To identify this line from the others in the vicinity, look for the mini roof with big side pull and undercling cracks. Starts up a left leaning corner/ramp.

6? bolts, 2 bolt anchor.

Multiple bouldery cruxes highlight this technical route with descent rests in between.  The business starts with a nice finger lock at the second bolt followed by a crimpy sequence into a small roof and then a difficult to decipher crux before a great rest.  The climbing is easier after the rest but some good footwork and a little strength is still required.  


Bolts

*This route technically starts mid wall. As I climbed it, Pat's Route straight in to Victoria Mordor, it is 40 m and 16 bolts. Plan on rapping twice, the anchors are over the top lip and back a meter or so. Bring a handful of longer draws to help straighten your rope line.

This line climbs the right facing dihedral high up on Tottering Pillar, this means trending right from the "Victoria Station", or straight up and then slightly left from "Pat's Route". 

From the "Pat's Route" anchors, continue straight up into a left facing corner/crack before crossing the face onto a small ledge at the base of the right facing corner/dihedral. Carefully stem up the dihedral on small holds until you can exit left just below the roof capping the dihedral. Pull an unbelievably exposed slab move onto the face above the roof you just avoided, and then follow the arete/face all the way over the top of the wall to hidden anchors. 

This line is unbelievably long, and very lonely and heady through delicate and exposed moves- an incredible experience. Plan on not being able to hear or see your belayer, and rapping twice. The first rap is ~30 m, tie your knots.  



Look for the prominent right facing corner/dihedral up high on Tottering Pillar. The corner is capped by a roof ~35 m off the deck. Aim for the bolt line just right of this corner system.

10* bolts, 2 bolt anchor (16 bolts with the Pat's Route link up)
This area contains a handful of moderate and long sport routes, with mostly vertical technical climbing.
